==Further reading== * {{cite book|author1=Sherry Sontag|author2=Christopher Drew|title=[[Blind Man's Bluff: The Untold Story of American Submarine Espionage]]|date=3 October 2000|publisher=HarperCollins|isbn=978-0-06-097771-9}} Covers this incident and also includes a description of the [[Walker spy ring]] role in its dangerous compromise of technical secrets of some of the tactical capabilities of U.S. Navy nuclear submarines and critical covert intelligence gathering operations during the Cold War. * {{cite book|author=Roger C. Dunham|title=Spy Sub: Top-Secret Mission to the Bottom of the Pacific|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KpTU_hW2icgC|accessdate=20 April 2013|date=1 June 1997|publisher=Onyx|isbn=978-0-451-40797-9}} * {{cite book|author1=W. Craig Reed|title=[[Red November: Inside the Secret U.S.-Soviet Submarine War]]|date=4 May 2010|publisher=William Morrow & Company |isbn=978-0-06-180676-6}} * Robert Williscroft (23 September 2014) ''Operation Ivy Bells''. Starman Press. {{ISBN|978-0982166277}} (a novel by one who was there.) * {{cite journal |first=Caitlin |last=Morris |title=Operation Ivy Bells: Lessons learned from an 'intelligence success' |journal=Journal of the Australian Institute of Professional Intelligence Officers |volume=20 |issue=3 |year=2012 |pages=17–29 |url=https://search.informit.com.au/documentSummary;dn=296641032846275;res=IELHSS }}

In many countries of the world, there has been a '''phase-out of lightweight plastic bags'''.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.marpolbul.2018.10.001 |title=Reducing marine pollution from single-use plastics (SUPs): A review |journal=Marine Pollution Bulletin |volume=137 |pages=157–171 |year=2018 |last1=Schnurr |first1=Riley E.J. |last2=Alboiu |first2=Vanessa |last3=Chaudhary |first3=Meenakshi |last4=Corbett |first4=Roan A. |last5=Quanz |first5=Meaghan E. |last6=Sankar |first6=Karthikeshwar |last7=Srain |first7=Harveer S. |last8=Thavarajah |first8=Venukasan |last9=Xanthos |first9=Dirk |last10=Walker |first10=Tony R. }}</ref><ref name="Xanthos">{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.marpolbul.2017.02.048 |pmid=28238328 |title=International policies to reduce plastic marine pollution from single-use plastics (plastic bags and microbeads): A review |journal=Marine Pollution Bulletin |volume=118 |issue=1–2 |pages=17–26 |year=2017 |last1=Xanthos |first1=Dirk |last2=Walker |first2=Tony R. }}</ref> Single-use [[plastic shopping bag]]s, commonly made from [[low-density polyethylene]] (LDPE) plastic,<ref name="plastic bags AU">{{cite web|url=http://www.environment.gov.au/settlements/waste/plastic-bags/index.html|title=Plastic bags|date=5 November 2009|publisher=Australian Government|accessdate=1 July 2012}}</ref> have traditionally been given free to customers by [[Retailing|stores]] when purchasing [[Good (economics)|goods]]—a popular method considered a strong, cheap, and [[hygienic]] way of transporting items. Problems associated with plastic bags include use of non-renewable resources (such as crude oil, gas and coal),<ref name="bag problems">{{cite web| url=http://www.ecorecycle.sustainability.vic.gov.au/resources/documents/Plastic_Bag_Free_Challenge_-_Factsheet.pdf| title=Plastic Bag Fact Sheet | date=9 November 2005| publisher=Sustainability Victoria| accessdate=1 July 2012|format= pdf}}</ref> disposal, and environmental impacts.
Governments all over the world have taken action to ban the sale of lightweight bags, charge customers for lightweight bags and/or generate taxes from the stores who sell them.<ref name="Xanthos"/><ref name="worldbag reduction">{{cite web|url=http://www.marrickville.nsw.gov.au/MARRICKVILLE/INTERNET/RESOURCES/DOCUMENTS/pdfs/bagbusters/around-the-world.pdf |title= Plastic bag reduction around the world| author= Kogoy, D| publisher=Marrickville Council| date= 8 November 2010|format=pdf}}</ref> The [[Bangladesh]] government was the first to do so in 2002, imposing a total ban on the bag.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-24090603|title=Plastic bag backlash gains momentum|first=Jane|last=Onyanga-Omara|date=14 September 2013|publisher=|via=www.bbc.co.uk|newspaper=BBC News}}</ref> Such a ban has also been applied in countries or regions such as [[Rwanda]], [[China]], [[Taiwan]], [[Republic of Macedonia|Macedonia]] and [[Kenya]].<ref name="worldbag reduction" /> Some countries in Europe impose a fee per bag. Bans, partial bans, and fees have been enacted by some local jurisdictions in North America, Australia, and Myanmar.<ref name="Xanthos"/> Concurrently with the reduction in lightweight plastic bags, shops have introduced [[reusable shopping bag]]s.

== Issues == [[File:Payatas-Dumpsite Manila Philippines02.jpg|thumb|250px|[[Plastic pollution|Plastic waste]] on the mounds of garbage in the [[Philippines]].]] Plastic bags cause many minor and major ecological and environmental issues. The most general issue with plastic bags is the amount of waste produced. Many plastic bags end up on streets and subsequently pollute major water sources, rivers, and streams.
Even when disposed of properly, they take many years to [[decompose]] and break down, generating large amounts of [[garbage]] over long periods of time. If not disposed of properly the bags can pollute [[waterways]], clog [[Sewerage|sewers]] and have been found in oceans affecting the [[habitat]] of [[animals]] and [[marine creatures]].<ref name="plastic bags AU" />
Two primary kinds of direct damage to wildlife are entanglement and ingestion.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://www.unep.org/regionalseas/marinelitter/publications/docs/trash_that_kills.pdf|title=Marine litter – trash that kills|accessdate=15 November 2016}}</ref> Wildlife animals or birds can become entangled. When the animals or birds are entangled they drown or cannot fly due to entanglement.<ref name="Plastic Waste and Wildlife">{{cite web|url=http://plasticwastesolutions.com/plastic-litter/#Plastic%20Waste%20and%20Wildlife|title=Plastic Waste and Wildlife|website=Plastic Waste Solutions|accessdate=1 January 2018}}</ref> Plastic bags are often [[ingested]] by animals because they cannot distinguish whether it is food or not. As a result, it clogs their intestines which results in death by starvation.<ref name="Plastic Waste and Wildlife"/> Plastic bags can block drains, trap birds and kill livestock. The [[World Wide Fund for Nature]] has estimated that over 100,000 whales, seals, and turtles die every year{{Citation needed|date=February 2014}} as a result of eating or being trapped by plastic bags. In India, an estimated number of 20 cows die per day as a result of ingesting plastic bags and having their digestive systems clogged by the bags. It is also very common across Africa to have sewers and drain systems clogged by bags which cause severe cases of malaria due to the increased population of mosquitoes that live on the flooded sewers.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.google.de/search?client=opera&q="Getting+Friendly+Environment"+"The+Dell+Challenge"&sourceid=opera&ie=UTF-8&oe=UTF-8|title=Getting Friendly Environment|publisher=The Dell Challenge|accessdate=28 January 2014}}</ref> The term "white pollution" has been coined in China to describe the local and global effects of discarded plastic bags upon the environment.<ref name=Watts2015>{{Cite news|last1=Watts|first1=Jonathan|title=China's biggest plastic bag maker closes after ban|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2008/feb/27/china.plasticbags|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=12 October 2015|date=27 February 2008|newspaper=The Guardian}}</ref>
Lightweight plastic bags are also blown into trees and other plants and can be mistaken for flowers by animals affecting their diet. Plastic bags break down, but they never biodegrade. As a result, any toxic additives they contain—including flame retardants, antimicrobials, and plasticizers—will be released into the environment. Many of those toxins directly affect the endocrine systems of organisms, which control almost every cell in the body.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Kiener|first=Robert|title=Plastic Pollution|journal=CQ Global Researcher|date=1 July 2010|pages=157–184}}</ref> Research shows the average operating "lifespan" of a plastic bag to be approximately 20 minutes.{{Citation needed|date=November 2016}} Plastic bags can last in landfill – an anaerobic environment – for up to 1000 years.{{Citation needed|date=November 2016}}
The plastic bags that get dumped in the Pacific Ocean would all eventually end up in the [[Great Pacific garbage patch]]. 80% of the plastic waste comes from land while the rest of the 20% comes from oil platforms and ships.<ref>{{cite web|title=Facts|url=http://garbagepatch.net/greatpacificoceangarbagepatchfacts/|website=Garbage Patch – The Great Pacific Garbage Patch and other pollution issues|accessdate=16 November 2016}}</ref> This large amount of plastic waste in the Pacific Ocean could be eaten up by marine animals, and this will end up blocking up their breathing passages and digestive systems. Plastic bags not only stay in the Great Pacific garbage patch, they can be washed back up to shore in beaches around the world.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Garces|first1=Diego|title=A staggering amount of waste – much of which has only existed for the past 60 years or so – enters the oceans each year.|url=http://wwf.panda.org/about_our_earth/blue_planet/problems/pollution/|website=World Wildlife Fund|publisher=World Wildlife Fund|accessdate=16 November 2016}}</ref>
== Regional developments ==
=== Africa ===
==== Benin ==== Benin reportedly banned plastic bags in November 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/view/articles/2017-11-08/stop-banning-plastic-bags-please|title=Stop Banning Plastic Bags, Please|date=8 November 2017|publisher=|accessdate=4 January 2018|via=www.bloomberg.com}}</ref>
==== Botswana ==== Botswana introduced a levy on plastic bags that became effective in 2007. This led to many retailers charging a fee on plastic bags and consequently a reduction in plastic bag use.<ref>Johane Dikgang and Martine Visser: [http://www.rff.org/rff/documents/EfD-DP-10-13.pdf "Behavioral Response to Plastic Bag Legislation in Botswana"], in ''Environment for Development'' Discussion Paper, May 2010</ref>
==== Burkina Faso ==== Burkina Faso banned non-biodegradable plastic bags in 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.unpei.org/latest-news/burkina-faso-endorses-law-on-sustainable-development-and-bans-non-biodegradable-plastic-bags|title=Burkina Faso endorses law on sustainable development and bans non-biodegradable plastic bags - UN Environment|website=www.unpei.org|accessdate=10 August 2018}}</ref>
==== Cameroon ==== Cameroon outlawed disposable plastic in April 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://africanarguments.org/2016/11/30/cameroon-bagging-it-after-the-plastic-ban/|title=Cameroon: bagging it after the plastic ban – African Arguments|date=30 November 2016|publisher=}}</ref> There are problems considering black market activities.
==== Chad ==== There is a plastic bag ban in N'Djamena.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.export.gov/article?id=Chad-Prohibited-Restricted-Imports|title=Chad - Prohibited & Restricted Imports - export.gov|website=www.export.gov|accessdate=27 November 2017}}</ref>
==== Republic of the Congo ==== The Republic of the Congo banned plastic bags in 2011.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/ozatp-congo-environment-plastic-20110602-idAFJOE7510G320110602|title=Congo bans plastic bags to fight pollution|first=Reuters|last=Editorial|publisher=|accessdate=23 March 2018|newspaper=Reuters|date=2011-06-02}}</ref>
==== Eritrea ==== Eritrea banned plastic bags in 2005.<ref>Department of Environmental Protection Florida: [http://www.dep.state.fl.us/waste/retailbags/pages/list_Africa.htm "Retail Bags Report – List of Retail Bag Policies"]</ref>
==== Ethiopia ==== Ethiopia has banned the production of certain types of plastic bags.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2017-05/22/c_136302987.htm|title=Ethiopia puts a squeeze on plastic bags – Xinhua – English.news.cn|website=news.xinhuanet.com|accessdate=27 November 2017}}</ref>
==== Gabon ==== Gabon has had a plastic bag ban since 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.panapress.com/Gabon-to-ban-plastic-bags,-introduces-biodegradable-bags--13-534258-18-lang2-index.html|title=Gabon to ban plastic bags, introduces biodegradable bags|website=www.panapress.com}}</ref>
==== Gambia ==== Gambia banned plastic bags in 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201505121229.html|title=Gambia: The Ban On Plastic Bag Use|website=allafrica.com}}</ref>
==== Guinea-Bissau ==== Guinea-Bissau banned plastic bags in 2016, but the legislation has been poorly enforced.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://trendtype.com/2017/04/17/guinea-bissau-retailers-hit-back-at-plastic-bag-ban/|title=Guinea-Bissau: retail hits back at plastic bag ban – Trendtype|date=17 April 2017|publisher=|accessdate=27 November 2017}}</ref>
==== Ivory Coast ==== Ivory Coast banned plastic bags in 2014, but it was controversial with water sellers.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-30198313|title=Plastic bag protest in Ivory Coast|date=25 November 2014|publisher=|accessdate=23 March 2018|via=www.bbc.co.uk|newspaper=BBC News}}</ref>
==== Kenya ==== [[Kenya]] tried to ban manufacture and import of plastic bags in the year 2007 and 2011 as a way to protect the environment.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/environment/kenya-bans-plastic-bags-2179928.html|title=Kenya bans plastic bags|date=9 January 2011|publisher=The Independent UK|accessdate=2 July 2012}}</ref> The 2007 and 2011 ban intended for plastics below 30 microns failed after manufacturers and retail outlets threatened to pass on the cost of using other materials to consumers.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.africareview.com/News/Nairobi-city-to-ban-use-of-plastic-bags/-/979180/2268346/-/laqh4lz/-/index.html |title =Nairobi city to ban use of plastic bags |date=3 April 2014 | publisher=Africa Review Kenya |accessdate=5 May 2015}}</ref> In 2017 the cabinet secretary of Environment and Natural resources, [[Judy Wakhungu|Prof Judy Wakhungu]] banned use, manufacture and importation of all plastic bags used for commercial and household packaging under Gazette notice number 2356.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.standardmedia.co.ke/business/article/2001232791/government-bans-use-of-plastic-bags|title=Government bans use of plastic bags|language=en|accessdate=2017-08-29}}</ref> On 28 August 2017, Kenya began implementing a countrywide ban of single-use plastic bags. Primary packaging bags, hospital waste bags, and garbage bin liners having been exempted from the ban. The ban has been hailed to be amongst the most stringent in the world. This includes a decision to imprison anyone involved in the creation or import of plastic bags for upwards of four years or will be forced to pay a fine between $19,000 and $38,000.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/28/world/africa/kenya-plastic-bags-ban.html|title=In Kenya, Selling or Importing Plastic Bags Will Cost You $19,000 — or Jail|last=Freytas-Tamura|first=Kimiko de|date=2017-08-28|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-11-28|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> Kenya joins more than 40 other countries to ban plastic bags.The government has promised to ban disposable plastic items in the near future.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2017/aug/28/kenya-brings-in-worlds-toughest-plastic-bag-ban-four-years-jail-or-40000-fine|title=Kenya brings in world's toughest plastic bag ban: four years jail or $40,000 fine|first=|last=Reuters|date=28 August 2017|publisher=|accessdate=27 November 2017|via=www.theguardian.com|newspaper=The Guardian}}</ref>
==== Madagascar ==== Madagascar introduced a plastic bag ban in 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://en.indian-ocean-times.com/Madagascar-Prohibition-of-the-use-of-plastic-bags-as-from-May-1-2015_a4602.html|title=Madagascar: Prohibition of the use of plastic bags as from May 1 2015|first=Antso|last=Rajaona|publisher=}}</ref>
==== Malawi ==== Malawi introduced a plastic bag ban in 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.times.mw/plastic-bag-manufacturers-honeymoon-ends-monday/|title=Plastic bag manufacturers' honeymoon ends Monday|work=Times.mw|date=27 June 2015}}</ref>
==== Mali ==== Mali has banned plastic bags.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.france24.com/en/20130103-2013-plastic-bag-ban-mauritania-mali|title=Could 2013 spell the end for plastic bags? – France 24|date=3 January 2013|publisher=|accessdate=27 November 2017}}</ref>
==== Mauritania ==== [[Mauritania]] banned the use, manufacture and import of plastic bags from January 2013 as a way to protect the environment, livestock, and marine species.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-20891539|title=Mauritania bans plastic bag use|date=3 January 2013|publisher=BBC|accessdate=3 July 2012|newspaper=BBC News}}</ref>
====Morocco==== [[Morocco]] passed a law in October 2015 banning the use of plastic bags nationwide. The law officially came into effect on 1 July 2016. Before the ban, Morocco was the 2nd largest consumer of plastic bags in Africa and the second in the world per capita after the United States.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.africanews.com/2016/07/01/morocco-enforcing-nationwide-ban-on-plastic-bags/|title=Morocco enforcing nationwide ban on plastic bags|date=1 July 2016 | publisher=Africanews|accessdate=4 July 2016}}</ref>
==== Mozambique ==== Mozambique has had a plastic bag charge since 5 February 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201601290496.html|title=Mozambique: Restrictions On Plastic Bags Take Effect On 5 February|date=29 January 2016|publisher=|via=AllAfrica}}</ref>
==== Niger ==== Niger has a plastic bag ban in force.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.panapress.com/Niger--Govt.-bans-production,-import,-trade,-use-of-plastic-bags--12-630408542-40-lang2-index.html|title=Niger: Govt. bans production, import, trade, use of plastic bags|website=www.panapress.com|accessdate=28 November 2017}}</ref>
====Rwanda==== Rwanda prohibited shops from giving away plastic bags to their customers in 2004.<ref>{{Cite news | title = Rwanda's war on plastic bags | work = BBC | accessdate = 2012-09-29 | date = 2004-10-04 | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/3714126.stm }}</ref> In 2008, Rwanda completely banned plastic bags as part of its Vision 2020 plan for sustainability, though there is a lucrative black market for the now banned product.<ref name="Rwanda">{{Cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2014/feb/15/rwanda-banned-plastic-bags-so-can-we | title=Think you can't live without plastic bags? Consider this: Rwanda did it | publisher=[[The Guardian]] | date=15 February 2014 | accessdate=14 September 2015 | author=Clavel, Émilie| newspaper=The Guardian }}</ref> The Rwandan government gave tax breaks for companies to recycle instead of manufacture plastic bags, and created a new market for environmentally friendly bags.<ref name="Rwanda" /> The lack of plastic bags has made Rwandan cities such as [[Kigali]] cleaner.<ref name="Rwanda" />
==== Senegal ==== Senegal has banned plastic bags in April 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/johnpaul-iwuoha/plastic-shopping-bags-wil_b_10277978.html|title=Plastic Shopping Bags Will Soon Be History Everywhere in Africa. Here's Why...|first=John-Paul|last=Iwuoha|date=3 June 2016|publisher=|accessdate=27 November 2017}}</ref>
==== Somalia ====
Plastic bags were banned in the self-declared Republic of Somaliland on 1 March 2005 after a 120-day grace period that the government had given to the public to get rid of their stocks. The Ministry of Trade and Industries announced the cabinet decision in a decree titled: "Banning importation, production and use of plastic bags in the country". The bags had been nicknamed "the Hargeysa flower", as many of them ended up being blown around and getting stuck in trees and shrubs, posing a danger to livestock because the animals that feed on the leaves often ingest the bags accidentally. In 2015 the ban was repeated by Presidential Decree No. #JSL/M/XERM/249-3178/042015, again providing for a 120 days grace period to get rid of stocks. To ensure the implementation of the ban, the government constituted enforcement teams in 2016 to conduct special drives which launch probes into business stalls. At least 1000 men and women in uniform deployed into the main markets and shopping malls. The government announced fines against violators who continue selling plastic bags in the country.<ref>[http://www.irinnews.org/report/53210/somalia-somaliland-bans-use-plastic-bags Somaliland bans use of plastic bags], IRIN News, 1 March 2005. Accessed on 30 October 2017.</ref><ref>[http://www.irinnews.org/feature/2005/03/24/somaliland-still-blighted-plastic-bags-despite-ban Somaliland still blighted by plastic bags, despite ban], IRIN News, 24 March 2005. Accessed on 30 October 2017.</ref><ref>[http://www.somalilandinformer.com/somaliland/somaliland-plastic-ban-enforcement-teams-formed-for-implementation/ Somaliland plastic ban: Enforcement teams formed for implementation], Somaliland Informer, 9 September 2016. Accessed on 30 October 2017.</ref><ref>[http://www.somalilandsun.com/politics1/government/7236-somaliland-ban-on-plastic-bags-imposed Somaliland: Ban on Plastic Bags Imposed], Somaliland Sun, 14 April 2015. Accessed on 30 October 2017.</ref><ref>[http://www.somalilandsun.com/images/PDF/warsaxaafadeed_Madaxweyne_14.04.2015_1.pdf The Official text of the Presidential decree (in Somali)]. Accessed on 30 October 2017.</ref>
==== South Africa ==== Plastic bags were a major concern in [[South Africa]] before the bag levy was introduced in 2004. The bags were never banned, but a levy was introduced, payable by the plastic bag manufacturer. The thicker plastic bags are levied and although this move initially caused outrage with consumers and an initial decline in volumes, consumers use has continually increased to several billion plastic shopping bags every year. http://www.econrsa.org/papers/p_papers/pp18.pdf <ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2008/04/080404-plastic-bags.html|title= Plastic-Bag Bans Gaining Momentum Around the World|date=4 April 2008|author=John Roach|publisher=National Geographic|accessdate=2 July 2012}}</ref>
==== South Sudan ==== South Sudan has banned lightweight plastic bags.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eyeradio.org/govt-bans-plastic-bags/|title=Gov't bans plastic bags|date=18 December 2017|publisher=|accessdate=10 August 2018}}</ref>
==== Sudan ==== [[Khartoum State]] has banned plastic bags.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://allafrica.com/stories/201709210130.html|title=Sudan: Khartoum State Bans Light Plastic Bags|date=21 September 2017|publisher=|accessdate=10 August 2018|via=AllAfrica|newspaper=Sudan News Agency (Khartoum)}}</ref>
====Tanzania==== The [[Revolutionary Government of Zanzibar|Revolutionary Government]] of [[Zanzibar]] banned plastic bags in 2005.<ref>{{Cite news | title = Zanzibar islands ban plastic bags | work = BBC | accessdate = 2012-09-29 | date = 2006-11-10 | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/6135886.stm }}</ref> [[Tanzania]] introduced a nationwide ban on plastic bags in 2006.<ref>{{Cite news | last = Pflanz | first = By Mike | title = Tanzania to ban all plastic bags | work = Telegraph.co.uk | accessdate = 2012-09-29 | date = 2006-04-04 | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/tanzania/1514793/Tanzania-to-ban-all-plastic-bags.html }}</ref>
==== Togo ==== Togo banned plastic bags in July 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/environment/togo-bans-plastic-bags-amid-growing-global-trend-2188205.html|title=Togo bans plastic bags amid growing global trend|publisher=|accessdate=26 September 2018|date=2011-01-19}}</ref>
==== Tunisia ==== [[Tunisia]] introduced a ban on plastic bag distribution in supermarkets starting from 1 March 2017. An agreement was signed between the Ministry of Local Affairs and Environment and large supermarket chains in the country to enact the first phase of a process aiming to reduce the consumption of plastic bags.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.treehugger.com/environmental-policy/tunisia-bans-disposable-plastic-shopping-bags.html|title=Tunisia bans disposable plastic shopping bags|work=TreeHugger|access-date=2017-03-27}}</ref> Tunisian activists are planning awareness campaigns to establish greener policies in the country.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thearabweekly.com/Environment/8063/Tunisia-bans-plastic-bags-in-supermarkets|title=Tunisia bans plastic bags in supermarkets|last=http://www.thearabweekly.com/|first=The Arab Weekly|website=The Arab Weekly|access-date=2017-04-10}}</ref>
====Uganda==== [[File:Trash in kampala.jpg|thumb|Heap of trash including plastic bags in Kampala, Uganda]]
[[Uganda]] introduced legislation in 2007 to ban the sale of lightweight plastic bags under 30 [[µm]] thick and tax thicker bags at a punitive rate of 120%. Although the laws came into effect in September of that year,<ref>{{Cite news | title = East African ban on plastic bags | work = BBC | accessdate = 2012-09-29 | date = 2007-06-14 | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/6754127.stm }}</ref> they have not been enforced and have failed to measurably reduce the use of plastic bags.<ref>{{Cite news | last = Tenywa | first = Gerald | title = Paper bag makers shift base as kaveera ghost hits with vengeance | work = New Vision | location = Kampala | accessdate = 2012-09-29 | date = 2009-01-11 | url = http://www.newvision.co.ug/D/9/36/667708 }}</ref> The law is not well enforced.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theeastafrican.co.ke/business/Manufacturers-plastic-bags-get-reprieve-/2560-3869798-f5s19xz/index.html|title=Makers of plastic bags get reprieve|publisher=|accessdate=27 November 2017}}</ref>
=== Asia ===
==== Bangladesh ==== A strict ban was introduced in Bangladesh in 2002 after floods caused by [[littered]] plastic bags submerged two-thirds of the country in water between 1988 and 1998.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.globaltvedmonton.com/top+5/6442656206/story.html|title=Top 5 places with plastic bag bans|date=7 June 2012|author=Nicole Bogart|publisher=Global News|accessdate=2 July 2012}}</ref> Plastic bags remain a big problem for sewerage system and waterways.
==== Bhutan ==== Bhutan has banned plastic bags, but the legislation has not been very effective so far.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbs.bt/news/?p=22302|title=Plastic ban still ineffective – BBS|date=14 January 2013|publisher=|accessdate=27 November 2017}}</ref>
==== Cambodia ==== Cambodia passed the legislation to impose a plastic bag tax in October 2017. Supermarkets now are charging customers 400 Riels (10 US cents) per plastic bag should they need one.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/asiapacific/cambodia-to-charge-customers-for-plastic-bags-9324502|title=Cambodia to charge customers for plastic bags|work=Channel News Asia|date=19 October 2017|accessdate=22 March 2018}}</ref>
==== China ==== A total plastic bag ban on ultra thin plastic bags and a fee on plastic bags was introduced in [[China]] on 1 June 2008. This came into effect because of the problems with sewerage and general waste. One 2009 survey suggests that plastic bag use fell between 60 and 80% in Chinese supermarkets, and 40 billion fewer bags were used. However, first hand accounts clearly indicate, the ban has seen limited success, and that the use of plastic bags remains prevalent. Street vendors and smaller stores, which make up a significant portion of retail in China, do not abide by the policy in part due to difficulties of enforcing the ban.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.chinadialogue.net/article/show/single/en/3158| title=China's bag ban, one year later| date=10 July 2009| author=Shi Jierui| publisher=China Dialogue| accessdate=3 July 2012}}</ref>
==== Hong Kong ==== [[Hong Kong]] forbids retailers from giving plastic bags under a certain thickness and for free.<ref name="worldbag reduction" /> A 50 cent plastic bag levy was implemented on 1 April 2015 across Hong Kong. The use of plastic bags dropped 90% after the introduction of the levy.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://english.cntv.cn/program/newshour/20110601/107359.shtml| title=Plastic bag ban abroad| date=6 January 2011|publisher=China Network Television|accessdate=3 July 2012}}</ref> Signs show that Hong Kong is phasing out the use of plastic bags at a dramatic rate.
[[File:Malpublicinfoboard.JPG|thumb|A sign proclaiming that polythene bags thinner than 30 µm are prohibited in [[Kasaragod]], [[Kerala]], India.]]
==== India ==== In 2002, [[India]] banned the production of plastic bags below 20 µm in thickness to prevent plastic bags from clogging of the municipal drainage systems and to prevent the cows of India ingesting plastic bags as they confuse it for food.<ref name="worldbag reduction" /><ref>{{cite web|title=plastic pollution: cow eating a plastic bag, near the Ganges River, Allahabad, India, 2007|url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/media/136513/A-cow-eating-a-plastic-bag-discarded-by-Hindu-devotees|publisher=Britannica|accessdate=17 December 2012}}</ref> However, enforcement remains a problem.
The Ministry of Environment, Forest and Climate Change has also passed regulation to ban all polythene bags less than 50 microns on 18 March 2016.<ref>{{cite web|title=Minimum Thickness of Plastic Carry Bags Increased from 40 to 50 Microns|url=http://pib.nic.in/newsite/PrintRelease.aspx?relid=138144|publisher=Ministry of Environment, Forest and Climate Change}}</ref> Due to poor implementation of this regulation, regional authorities(states and municipal corporations), have had to implement their own regulation.
In 2016, Sikkim, India's first fully organic state,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/sikkim-becomes-indias-first-organic-state/article8107170.ece|title=India's first organic state|newspaper=The Hindu|date=2016-01-14}}</ref> banned the use of not only packaged drinking water bottles in any government meetings or functions but also food containers made from polystyrene foam all over the state.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://food.ndtv.com/food-drinks/sikkim-becomes-the-first-indian-state-to-ban-mineral-water-bottles-in-govt-programmes-1409904|title=Ban on plastic bottles}}</ref>
Himachal Pradesh was the first state to ban plastic bags less than 30 µm. The Karnataka state became first state to ban all forms of plastic carry bags, plastic banners, plastic buntings, flex, plastic flags, plastic plates, plastic cups, plastic spoons, cling films and plastic sheets for spreading on dining tables irrespective of thickness including the above items made of thermacol and plastic which uses plastic micro beads.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/bengaluru/Total-plastic-ban-in-Karnataka/articleshow/51397198.cms|title=Total plastic ban in Karnataka}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://bangalore.citizenmatters.in/articles/karnataka-plastic-ban-petition-order-march-2016|title=HC refuses to stay plastic ban; asks plastic industry to go to Green Tribunal|date=2016-03-30}}</ref> The state of Goa has banned bags up to 40 µm thick,<ref>{{cite web|last=TNN|title=Plea to relax ban on plastic bags below 40 microns|url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2013-05-20/goa/39391935_1_plastic-bags-state-pollution-control-board-jose-manuel-noronha|publisher=The Times of India|accessdate=30 May 2013|date=20 May 2013}}</ref> while the city of [[Mumbai]] bans bags below a minimum thickness to 50 µm.<ref>{{cite web|last=Press Trust of India|title=Mumbai to ban plastic bags; to amend law|url=http://www.dnaindia.com/mumbai/1330196/report-mumbai-to-ban-plastic-bags-to-amend-law|publisher=Diligent Media Corporation Ltd.|accessdate=30 May 2013|date=2 January 2010}}</ref>
The state Government of [[Maharashtra]] banned plastic starting 23 June 2018.<ref>{{cite web|title=Plastic Waste Management in Maharashtra|url=http://mpcb.gov.in/plastic/plastic.php|publisher=Maharashtra Pollution Control Board|accessdate=22 June 2018|date=23 June 2018}}</ref>
==== Indonesia ==== Starting in 2016, Environment Ministry enforced retailers in 23 cities across the archipelago (mini-market, hypermarket, and supermarket) to charge consumers for plastic bags between Rp.200 and Rp.5,000 for each bag including degradable plastic bags. And money which came from tax are used by retailers as public funds for waste management alongside non-governmental organizations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/asiapacific/indonesia-launches/2534464.html|title=Indonesia launches campaign to reduce use of plastic bags|date=21 February 2016|author=Sujadi Siswo|accessdate=26 February 2016}}</ref>
==== Israel ==== Since January 2017, large retailers are required to charge consumers for plastic bags with handles, at [[Israeli new shekel|NIS]] 0.10 for each bag. The tax revenues will be used to fund public waste-management programs.{{citation needed|date=December 2016}} The average use of plastic bags in Israel in 2014 was 275 per person per year.<ref>Udasin, Sharon: [http://www.jpost.com/Enviro-Tech/Knesset-bills-seeks-to-alleviate-scourge-of-plastic-shopping-bags-in-Israel-340958 "Knesset bills seeks to alleviate scourge of plastic shopping bags in Israel "], in ''[[The Jerusalem Post]]'', 10 February 2014</ref> Four months after the law came into force, the number of disposable plastic bags distributed by retailers subject to the law had dropped by 80%.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.globes.co.il/en/article-disposable-plastic-bag-use-falls-1001190032|title=Disposable plastic bag use falls very sharply – Globes English|website=Globes|accessdate=27 November 2017}}</ref>
==== Japan ==== Legislation in Japan varies by region, from outright bans to none at all.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.japanfs.org/en/news/archives/news_id035126.html|title=Current Status of Plastic Bag Reduction Efforts in Japan｜JFS Japan for Sustainability|publisher=}}</ref>
==== Kazakhstan ==== Kazakhstan is considering a plastic bag ban.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.tj/en/news/centralasia/20171226/kazakhstan-authorities-decide-to-abolish-plastic-shopping-bags|title=Kazakhstan authorities decide to abolish plastic shopping bags - Tajikistan News ASIA-Plus|publisher=|accessdate=23 March 2018}}</ref>
==== Kyrgyzstan ==== Kyrgyzstan is considering a plastic bag ban.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://24.kg/english/75474__Kyrgyzstan_intends_to_prohibit_use_of_plastic_bags/|title=Kyrgyzstan intends to prohibit use of plastic bags|first=Anastasia|last=BENGARD|date=8 February 2018|publisher=|accessdate=23 March 2018}}</ref>
==== Malaysia ==== A tax on plastic bags applies in [[Penang]],<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.penang.gov.my/index.php/ms/pusat-media/koleksi-ucapan-yab-km/638-launching-of-no-free-plastic-bags-day-at-tesco-sg-dua| title=Launching of No Free Plastic Bags Day at Tesco Sg Dua| date=24 January 2011| publisher=Penang Government| accessdate=2 July 2012}}</ref> while a similar tax in the state of [[Selangor]] applies only on Saturdays, since 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2010/1/3/nation/20100103204118&sec=nation|title=Selangor implements 'No Plastic Day' every Saturday|date=3 January 2010|author=Shaun Ho|publisher=The Star|accessdate=2 July 2012}}</ref>
==== Myanmar ==== In 2009, plastic bag factories in [[Rangoon]] were ordered by local authorities to stop production by the end of November or face heavy punishment, as the [[Burmese government]] looked to ban plastic bags. Rangoon was thus following in the footsteps of central Burma's [[Mandalay]] and the new capital [[Naypyidaw]], both of which had eliminated plastic bags.
==== Nepal ==== Nepal has banned plastic bags, but the legislation is poorly enforced.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://thehimalayantimes.com/kathmandu/ban-production-use-plastic-bags-comes-effect/|title=Ban on production and use of plastic bags comes into effect|date=17 July 2016|publisher=|accessdate=27 November 2017}}</ref>
==== Oman ==== A plastic bag ban is being planned by the Omani government.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://timesofoman.com/article/135834|title=Oman set to ban all plastic bags: Ministry|publisher=|accessdate=26 September 2018|date=2018-06-04}}</ref>
==== Pakistan ==== There are plastic bag bans in parts of Pakistan, but there is poor enforcement.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://dailytimes.com.pk/83132/despite-ban-production-and-use-of-plastic-bags-continues/|title=Despite ban, production and use of plastic bags continues – Daily Times|date=10 May 2016|publisher=|accessdate=27 November 2017}}</ref>
==== Philippines ==== There is a plastic bag ban in Manila, but it is poorly enforced.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://manilastandard.net/sunday-lgu-section-pdf/ncr/243787/-enforce-plastic-bag-law-in-manila-.html|title=Enforce plastic bag law in Manila|publisher=|accessdate=27 November 2017}}</ref>
==== South Korea ==== South Korea banned the distribution of lightweight plastic bags from supermarkets and bakeries in August 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.upi.com/Top_News/World-News/2018/08/02/South-Korea-bans-disposable-coffee-cups-plastic-bags/6841533181415/|title=South Korea bans disposable coffee cups, plastic bags|publisher=|accessdate=10 August 2018}}</ref>
==== Sri Lanka ==== Sri Lanka banned plastic bags in 2017 due to a waste crisis.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/afp/article-4843304/Sri-Lanka-bans-plastic-garbage-crisis.html|work=Daily Mail|title=Sri Lanka bans plastic after garbage crisis|date=1 September 2017|accessdate=22 March 2018}}</ref>
==== Taiwan ==== In January 2003, [[Taiwan]] banned the free distribution of lightweight plastic bags.<ref name="asia bag ban">{{cite web| url=http://www.dep.state.fl.us/waste/retailbags/pages/list_Asia.htm| title=Retail Bags Report – List of Retail Bag Policies – Asia| date=11 March 2011| publisher=Department of Environmental Protection Florida| accessdate=3 July 2012}}</ref> The ban prevented the owners of department stores, shopping malls, hypermarkets, convenience stores, fast food restaurants and regular restaurants from providing free plastic bags to their customers. Many stores have replaced plastic with recycled paper boxes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.plastics.ca/_files/file.php?fileid=itemaYpTfnQNnF&filename=file_WHY_PLASTIC_SHOPPING_BAG_BANS_AND_TAXES_DON_T_WORK.doc|title=Why plastic shopping bag bans and taxes don't work|publisher=Canadian Plastics Industry Association|accessdate=2 July 2012|format=doc}}</ref> In 2006, however, the administration decided to begin allowing free plastic bags to be offered by food service operators.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2006/12/18/2003340889|title=Many support EPA ban on throw-away utensils|work=taipeitimes.com|accessdate=6 October 2015}}</ref> In February 2018, Taiwan announced plans to ban plastic bags in varying degrees, banned for in-store use by 2019, certain stores prohibited from offering bags by 2020, price increases starting 2025, then 2030 blanket ban of single-use plastic bags, as well as single-use utensils and containers.<ref>{{cite web |title=Taiwan to ban disposable plastic items by 2030 |url=https://www.straitstimes.com/asia/east-asia/taiwan-to-ban-disposable-plastic-items-by-2030 |website=The Straits Times |publisher=AFP |accessdate=4 June 2018 |language=en |date=22 February 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Everington |first1=Keoni |title=Taiwan EPA sets timeline for ban on plastic straws {{!}} Taiwan News |url=https://www.taiwannews.com.tw/en/news/3363954 |website=Taiwan News |accessdate=4 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=McCarthy |first1=Joe |title=Taiwan Announces Ban on All Plastic Bags, Straws, and Utensils |url=https://www.globalcitizen.org/en/content/taiwan-ban-on-plastic-bags-straws-utensils-contain/ |website=Global Citizen |accessdate=4 June 2018}}</ref>
=== Europe ===
==== European Union ==== In November 2013, the European Commission published a proposal aiming to reduce the consumption of lightweight (thickness below 50 microns) plastic carrier bags.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_IP-13-1017_en.htm| title=EUROPA – Press release – Environment: Commission proposes to reduce the use of plastic bags| publisher=European Commission| accessdate=31 March 2014}}</ref> Under the proposal, EU member states can choose the most appropriate measures to discourage the use of plastic bags. On 29 April 2015 the European Parliament passed [[Directive (European Union)|Directive]] 2015/720 to reduce plastic bag use by 50% by 2017 and 80% by 2019.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.euractiv.com/section/sustainable-dev/news/eu-to-halve-plastic-bag-use-by-2019/|title=EU to halve plastic bag use by 2019|author=Cécile Barbière|work=Euractiv|date=29 April 2015|accessdate=30 July 2018}}</ref><!-- News source says it passed on the 28th, but the directive itself is dated 29th --><ref>{{cite EU directive |serial=2015/720 |year=2015 |date=29 April 2015 |description=amending Directive 94/62/EC as regards reducing the consumption of lightweight plastic carrier bags |eurlextag=celex%3A32015L0720 }}</ref>
==== Albania ==== Albania has banned lightweight plastic bags as of 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://emerging-europe.com/news/albania-bans-lightweight-plastic-bags/|title=Albania bans lightweight plastic bags - Emerging-Europe.com|date=31 July 2018|publisher=|accessdate=9 August 2018}}</ref>
==== Austria ==== Austria has a voluntary agreement in place whereby retailers apply a charge to bags.<ref name="surfrider.eu">{{cite web|url=http://www.surfrider.eu/wp-content/uploads/2017/06/report_EUMemberStateslegislations_PlasticBags_web_en.pdf|title=ENOUGH EXCUSES: Time for Europe to act against plastic bag pollution.|work=Surfrider Foundation Europe}}</ref>
==== Belgium ==== Belgium has plastic bag bans in place in Wallonia and Brussels, with bans set to also be introduced to Flanders.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ff-packaging.com/plastic-bags-law-belgium/|title=Plastic bags law in Belgium • FF Packaging|first=Keraweb -|last=http://www.keraweb.nl/|publisher=|accessdate=27 November 2017}}</ref>
==== Bosnia and Herzegovina ==== The government of Bosnia and Herzegovina has reportedly introduced a adopted a decree on fees for retailers offering lightweight plastic bags.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://balkangreenenergynews.com/albania-to-ban-lightweight-plastic-bags-on-july-4/|title=Albania to ban lightweight plastic bags on July 4|date=19 June 2018|publisher=|accessdate=26 September 2018}}</ref> It is not known whether the law has entered into force yet.
==== Bulgaria ==== Bulgaria has seen a significant reduction in use since applying a charge to plastic bags.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.novinite.com/articles/168268/Bulgaria%E2%80%99s+Environment+Ministry+Reports+Substantial+Reduction+in+Plastic+Bag+Use|title=Bulgaria's Environment Ministry Reports Substantial Reduction in Plastic Bag Use – Novinite.com – Sofia News Agency|publisher=|accessdate=27 November 2017}}</ref>
==== Croatia ==== Croatia is planning on introducing a plastic bag charge in 2019.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.total-croatia-news.com/business/22586-from-2019-no-more-free-lightweight-plastic-bags-in-supermarkets|title=From 2019, No More Free Plastic Bags in Croatian Stores|publisher=|accessdate=3 January 2018}}</ref>
==== Cyprus ==== Cyprus introduced a bag charge on 1 January 2018, though shops were reportedly ignoring the new law.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cyprus-mail.com/2018/01/04/shops-ignoring-plastic-bag-ban/|title=Shops ignoring plastic bag ban – Cyprus Mail|date=4 January 2018|publisher=}}</ref> Shops began to be penalised for handing out free bags after 1 July 2018.
==== Czech Republic ==== The Czech Republic has a plastic bag levy in place.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.expats.cz/community/czechia-says-goodbye-to-free-plastic-bags/|title=Czech Republic Says Goodbye to Free Plastic Bags|date=3 February 2017|publisher=|accessdate=27 November 2017}}</ref>
==== Denmark ==== In 2003, [[Denmark]] introduced a tax on retailers giving out plastic bags. This encouraged stores to charge for plastic bags and pushed the use of reusable bags. It was thought that this saved about 66% of plastic and paper bags.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.reuseit.com/learn-more/top-facts/trends-from-around-the-world| title=Learn About Global Efforts to Reduce Waste from Disposable Products| publisher=Reuse it| accessdate=3 July 2012}}</ref> In 2004, a similar law was passed by the ''Inatsisartut ''in Greenland, which applied a recycling tax on plastic bags.<ref>http://www.ina.gl/demokratihome/publikationer.aspx?docgallery=10554</ref> By 2014 Denmark had the lowest plastic bag use in Europe, with 4 bags per person per year, compared to 466 in Portugal, Poland and Slovakia.<ref name="ABC 2014">[http://www.abc.net.au/environment/articles/2014/04/17/3987712.htm "Europe votes to slash plastic bag use"], ABC News, 17 April 2014</ref>
==== Estonia ==== Estonia introduced a bag tax in July 2017.<ref name="surfrider.eu"/>
==== Finland ==== Finland applies a tax to plastic bags through a voluntary agreement.<ref name="zerowasteeurope.eu">{{cite web|url=https://www.zerowasteeurope.eu/2017/07/ditching-plastic-bags-a-lesson-from-africa/|title=Ditching Plastic Bags: A Lesson from Africa – Zero Waste Europe|date=3 July 2017|publisher=|accessdate=27 November 2017}}</ref><ref name="surfrider.eu"/>
==== France ==== Following a National Assembly vote on 11 October 2014, France banned plastic carrier bags under 50 microns starting 1 July 2016. Produce bags are banned starting 1 January 2017. Re-usable or compostable bags are allowed.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Robert|first1=Aline|title=France postpones plastic bag ban for six months|url=https://www.euractiv.com/section/sustainable-dev/news/france-postpones-plastic-bag-ban-for-six-months/|website=EurActiv.fr|accessdate=14 November 2016|date=19 November 2015}}</ref>
==== Georgia ==== Georgia has reportedly banned plastic bags, as of 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hetq.am/eng/news/84469/armenia-fails-to-ban-plastic-bags-taxing-them-could-generate-$215-million-for-the-government.html|title=Armenia Fails to Ban Plastic Bags. Taxing Them Could Generate $215 Million for the Government – Hetq – News, Articles, Investigations|publisher=|accessdate=3 January 2018}}</ref>
==== Germany ==== Germany imposes a fee on excess packaging through its [[Green Dot (symbol)|Green Dot]] program, which included plastic bags.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.howtogermany.com/pages/recycling.html|title=How To Germany – All About Recycling in Germany|website=www.howtogermany.com|access-date=2016-03-13}}</ref> In addition, all stores in [[Germany]] that provide plastic bags must pay a recycling tax.<ref name="bigfatbags.co.uk">{{Cite news|url=http://www.bigfatbags.co.uk/bans-taxes-charges-plastic-bags/|title=List by country; 'bag charges, taxes and bans'. – Big Fat Bags|newspaper=Big Fat Bags|language=en-US|access-date=2016-11-15}}</ref>
An agreement was signed between trade representatives and the [[Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conservation, Building and Nuclear Safety]] in April 2016 to reduce plastic bags, excepting thin bags for fruit and vegetables, bags for deep-freeze products and long-term usable bags,<ref name="umweltbundesamt-2016">{{Cite web|url=http://www.umweltbundesamt.de/themen/ende-der-kostenlosen-plastiktueten-fragen-antworten|title=Ende der kostenlosen Plastiktüten – Fragen und Antworten|publisher=Umweltbundesamt|date=2016-06-02|accessdate=2017-08-31|language=de}}</ref> resulting in many shops no longer offer such plastic bags free of cost since July 2016. Should the goal not be achieved, it is foreseen that a law may be passed banning shops from handing them out.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bundesregierung.de/Content/DE/Artikel/2016/04/2016-04-26-plastiktueten.html|title=Plastiktüten ab Juli kostenpflichtig|publisher=Umweltbundesamt|date=2016-04-26|accessdate=2017-08-31|language=de}}</ref> The political background to this is a recent change to the European directive 94/62/EG that obliges the member states to reduce the yearly number of plastic bags per capita down to maximally 90 by end-2019 and to maximally 40 by end-2025, whereas Germany had been using 70 bags per capita so far.<ref name="umweltbundesamt-2016"/>
==== Greece ==== A plastic bag charge was introduced on 1 January 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ekathimerini.com/224103/article/ekathimerini/news/free-plastic-shopping-bags-banned-from-start-of-new-year|title=Free plastic shopping bags banned from start of new year – Kathimerini|publisher=|accessdate=3 January 2018}}</ref> Bags cost 4 cents each, which will then increase to 7 cents on 1 January 2019.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chaniapost.eu/2017/10/01/plastic-bags-to-cost-3-cents-each-in-greece-after-january-1/|title=Plastic bags to cost 4 cents each in Greece after January 1 – CretePost.gr|website=www.chaniapost.eu|accessdate=28 November 2017}}</ref>
==== Hungary ==== Hungary has a voluntary agreement with retailers whereby they apply a charge to bags.<ref name="surfrider.eu"/>
==== Ireland ==== [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]] introduced a €0.15 tax in March 2002. Levied on consumers at the point of sale, this led to 90% of consumers using long-life bags within a year. The tax was increased to €0.22 in 2007. The revenue is put into an Environment Fund.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-17027990|title=What should be done about plastic bags?|newspaper=BBC News|accessdate=6 October 2015|date=2012-03-19|last1=Summers|first1=Chris}}</ref>
==== Italy ==== In January 2011, [[Italy]] banned the distribution of lightweight plastic bags that are not from biodegradable sources.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.environmentalleader.com/2011/01/06/italy-carries-out-plastic-bag-ban| title=Italy Carries Out Plastic Bag Ban| date=6 January 2011|publisher=Environmental Leader|accessdate=3 July 2012}}</ref>
==== Latvia ==== Latvia will introduce a bag charge on 1 January 2019.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bnn-news.com/stores-in-latvia-will-no-longer-provide-plastic-bags-free-of-charge-178081|title=Stores in Latvia will no longer provide plastic bags free of charge|date=11 January 2018|publisher=}}</ref>
==== Lithuania ==== Lithuania will introduce a bag charge on 31 December 2018.<ref name="surfrider.eu"/>
==== Luxembourg ==== Luxembourg applies a tax to plastic bags.<ref name="zerowasteeurope.eu"/>
==== Malta ==== Malta has had an eco-tax on plastic bags since 2009, but it is poorly enforced.<ref name="surfrider.eu"/>
==== Moldova ==== The Moldovan parliament has passed legislation banning plastic bags. It came into force for larger retailers in 2017, came into force for medium-sized retailers on 1 January 2018 and is scheduled for small retailers in 2020.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://a-tv.md/eng/index.php?newsid=32715|title=Plastic bags are banned in Moldova » Accent TV|website=a-tv.md|accessdate=28 November 2017}}</ref>
==== Netherlands ==== The Netherlands implemented a comprehensive ban on free plastic shopping bags on 1 January 2016. The ban has a small number of exemptions for unpacked food products which are exposed to possible contamination, such as fresh fruit. The target price for a plastic bag is €0.25.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.rijksoverheid.nl/onderwerpen/afval/inhoud/verbod-op-gratis-plastic-tassen|title=Verbod op gratis plastic tassen – Afval – Rijksoverheid.nl|last=Milieu|first=Ministerie van Infrastructuur en|website=www.rijksoverheid.nl|language=nl-NL|access-date=2016-03-30|date=2015-08-26}}</ref>
==== Norway ==== Norway has a voluntary agreement with retailers whereby they apply a charge to bags.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thelocal.no/20171003/plastic-bag-charge-on-way-to-norway|title=Plastic bag charge carries to Norway|date=3 October 2017|publisher=}}</ref>
==== Poland ==== A plastic recycling levy was introduced on 1 January 2018. Single-use plastic bags cost a minimum of {{currency|0.25|PLN}} (inclusive of VAT), however stores are able to charge a higher amount.<ref>{{cite web |title=Koniec z darmowymi reklamówkami. Jakie są ceny foliówek w supermarketach? |url=https://www.wprost.pl/gospodarka/10095657/koniec-z-darmowymi-reklamowkami-jakie-sa-ceny-foliowek-w-supermarketach.html |publisher=[[Wprost]] |accessdate=28 September 2018|date=2018-01-02 }}</ref> The Polish government estimated that the levy would bring 1.1 billion złoty to the state budget in 2018, in addition to approx. 250 million złoty of VAT revenue raised on sales of the bags.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://podatki.gazetaprawna.pl/artykuly/1092914,oplata-recyklingowa-2018-ceny-workow-foliowych.html |title=Opłata recyklingowa w 2018 roku. Fiskus zarobi ćwierć miliarda złotych na sprzedaży foliówek |last=Pokojska |first=Agnieszka |date=2017-12-19 |website=Gazeta Prawna |access-date=2018-09-28}}</ref>
==== Portugal ====
Portugal has implemented a plastic bag tax amounting to 10 cents (€) on single-use carrier bags, which led to a reduction of 90% in their use.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theportugalnews.com/news/plastic-bag-use-plummets-a-year-after-tax-introduction/37473|title=Plastic bag use plummets a year after tax introduction|publisher=|accessdate=27 November 2017}}</ref> However, many retailers started selling thicker (reusable) plastic bags, which are not subject to the tax, for the same amount. Before the Portuguese government implemented this plastic bag tax, some supermarkets in Portugal had already implemented a 2 cent (€) fee on each plastic bag.<ref name=":0">{{cite journal |doi=10.1080/09640568.2010.490054 |title=The influence of a voluntary fee in the consumption of plastic bags on supermarkets from Madeira Island (Portugal) |journal=Journal of Environmental Planning and Management |volume=53 |issue=7 |pages=883–889 |year=2010 |last1=Luís |first1=Idalina Perestrelo |last2=Spínola |first2=Hélder }}</ref> In Madeira Island where supermarkets implemented this bag fee, there was a 64% reduction in plastic bag consumption.<ref name=":0" />
==== Romania ==== A law was introduced in 2006 (law 578/2006) - and was later modified in 2011 (law 1032/2011) – that puts a mandatory tax on non-biodegradable plastic bags. The modification in 2011 reduced the tax on plastic bags and was regarded by some as a step backwards from environmental protection.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://legestart.ro/ecotaxa-pe-pungi-si-sacose-pentru-cumparaturi| title=Ecotaxa pe pungi şi sacoşe pentru cumpărături| date=2011-06-02}}</ref>
==== Serbia ==== Serbia has a tax on manufacturers and importers of plastic bags<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.balkaninsight.com/en/article/serbia-says-good-bye-to-plastic-bags|title=Serbia Throws Plastic Bags in Dustbin of History :: Balkan Insight|website=www.balkaninsight.com|accessdate=28 November 2017}}</ref> and plans to introduce a ban on lightweight plastic bags and a charge on biodegradable bags in order to reduce bag use to under 90 per person by 2019.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://rs.n1info.com/a381027/English/NEWS/Serbia-to-ban-plastic-bags.html|title=Serbia set to ban plastic bags|publisher=|accessdate=10 August 2018}}</ref> Major supermarkets began charging 2 [[Serbian dinar|dinars]] per bag in 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.novosti.rs/vesti/beograd.74.html:738728-NAPLATA-PLASTICNE-AMBALAZE-Traze-dva-dinara-za-kesu|title=NAPLATA PLASTIČNE AMBALAŽE: Traže dva dinara za kesu|lang=sr|publisher=[[Večernje novosti]]|date=17 July 2018|accessdate=26 November 2018}}</ref>
==== Slovakia ==== Slovakia has an obligatory charge for certain types of plastic bags. The charge was introduced on 1 January 2018.<ref>Scottish Government</ref>
==== Slovenia ==== Slovenia plans to ban free lightweight plastic bags from 1 January 2019.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://english.sta.si/2406444/govt-bans-free-lightweight-plastic-bags-as-of-2019|title=STA: Govt bans free lightweight plastic bags as of 2019|website=english.sta.si|accessdate=29 April 2018}}</ref>
==== Spain ==== Spain introduced a plastic bag charge on 1 July 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thinkspain.com/news-spain/28650/charging-for-carrier-bags-to-be-mandatory-in-spain-from- 2018|title=Charging for carrier bags to be mandatory in Spain from 2018|publisher=}}</ref> Catalonia has had a bag charge since April 2017.<ref name="surfrider.eu"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thinkspain.com/news-spain/30531/carrier-bag-charges-compulsory-from-july-this-year|title=Carrier bag charges compulsory from July this year|publisher=|accessdate=18 July 2018}}</ref>
==== Sweden ==== Sweden has a plastic bag levy in place.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rcinet.ca/eye-on-the-arctic/2016/07/06/sweden-fees-plastic-bags-environment-ocean/|title=Sweden considers higher fees for plastic bags|date=6 July 2016|publisher=|accessdate=27 November 2017}}</ref>
==== Switzerland ==== {{See also|Environmental movement in Switzerland|Waste management in Switzerland}}
In 2016, the two largest chains of supermarkets in Switzerland, the [[Federation of Migros Cooperatives]] and [[Coop (Switzerland)|Coop]], announced that they will progressively stop to distribute free plastic bags (at the check-out).<ref name=Guillaume>{{fr}} Michel Guillaume, "L'économie suisse promet de verdir", ''[[Le temps]]'', Monday 26 September 2016, page 4. Published on-line as [https://www.letemps.ch/suisse/2016/09/25/leconomie-suisse-promet-verdir-malgre-rejet-linitiative "L'économie suisse promet de verdir malgré le rejet de l'initiative"] on 25 September 2016 (page visited on 26 September 2016).</ref> Both distributors announced that they will not make money with paid bags, but that profits from their sale will be invested in environmental projects.<ref name=RTS/>
[[Migros]] previously tested the measure in the [[Canton of Vaud]] since 2013: they reduced the number of plastic bags distributed by ninety percent (and saved 100,000 [[Swiss francs|francs]] per year).<ref name=Guillaume/><ref name=West>{{fr}} Michael West, "Environnement. « Petits prix pour grands effets »", ''Migros magazine'', number 39, 29 September 2016, page 38-39.</ref> Migros will be the first to introduce the measure across the country, on 1 November 2016 (the bags will be made with recycled plastic and cost 0.05 [[Swiss francs]] each).<ref name=Guillaume/><ref name=West/> [[Coop (Switzerland)|Coop]] plans to introduce this in 2017.<ref name=RTS>{{fr}} [http://www.rts.ch/info/economie/8036213-chez-coop-et-migros-les-sacs-jetables-vont-desormais-couter-5-centimes.html "Chez Coop et Migros, les sacs jetables vont désormais coûter 5 centimes"], [[Radio télévision suisse]], 22 September 2016 (page visited on 25 September 2016).</ref>
==== Turkey ==== Plastic bags are banned is some parts of Turkey<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/plastic-bags-to-be-banned-on-istanbuls-princes-islands-95429|title=Plastic bags to be banned on Istanbul's Princes' Islands|website=Hürriyet Daily News|accessdate=27 November 2017}}</ref> and a levy was scheduled to be introduced nationally in January 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.plasteurope.com/news/TURKEY_t236614/|title=TURKEY: Introduction of fees for retail plastic bags from January 2018 / Ban on thin plastic bags|first=Jens|last=Hartmann|website=www.plasteurope.com|accessdate=27 November 2017}}</ref>
==== United Kingdom ====
The [[Climate Change Act 2008]] served as the legislative framework for the regulation of plastic bags in the United Kingdom.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Everett|first=Michael|last2=Priestley|first2=Sara|title=The 5p Plastic Bag Charge|url=http://researchbriefings.parliament.uk/ResearchBriefing/Summary/CBP-7241#fullreport|date=2017-06-22}}</ref>
=====Wales===== Wales introduced a legal minimum charge of 5 pence for almost all single use bags in October 2011. Paper and biodegradable bags are included in the charge as well as plastic bags, with only a few specific exemptions – such as for unpackaged food or medicine supplied on an [[NHS Wales|NHS]] prescription. [[Value added tax|VAT]] raised from the charge is collected by the government. Retailers are asked to pass the rest of the proceeds on to charities.<ref>{{cite web|title=Retailers|url=http://www.carrierbagchargewales.gov.uk/retailers/?lang=en|work=Carrier bag charge Wales|publisher=Crown|accessdate=4 August 2013|date=July 2013}}</ref> July 2012 statistics released by the Welsh Government suggested that carrier bag use in Wales had reduced 96% since the introduction of the charge.<ref name="bigfatbags.co.uk"/>
=====Northern Ireland===== [[Northern Ireland]] introduced a 5 pence levy on almost all single use bags on 8 April 2013. The levy will be extended to reusable carrier bags with a retail price of less than 20 pence from 19 January 2014<ref>{{cite web|title=NI Direct Bag Levy|url=http://www.nidirect.gov.uk/baglevy|website=Carrier bag Levy Northern Ireland|publisher=NI Direct|date=2015-11-20}}</ref> as data from a number of retailers indicate that reusable bag sales have increased by 800% since the introduction of the levy on single use bags. The proceeds of the levy (£4.17m in 2013/14) are paid to the Department of the Environment and used to fund local environmental projects and enforce the levy. Official statistics for the Northern Ireland levy show that the number of single use bags dispensed fell from around 300 million in 2012/13 to 84.5 million in 2013/14 – a reduction of 72%.<ref>{{cite web|title=NI Bag Levy Annual Statistics 2013/14|url=http://www.doeni.gov.uk/carrier_bag_levy_-_annual_statistics_2013-14.pdf|website=Carrier bag Levy Northern Ireland Statistics|publisher=DOE NI|date=August 2014}}</ref>
=====Scotland===== A five pence minimum charge for single-use carrier bags came into force in [[Scotland]] on 20 October 2014. The proceeds of the charge can be used by the retailers as they see fit,<ref name=independent-scot>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/scotlands-5p-carrier-bag-charge-comes-into-effect-9806706.html|title=Scotland's 5p carrier bag charge comes into effect|author=Natasha Culzac|date=20 October 2014|work=The Independent|accessdate=6 October 2015}}</ref> although retailers are encouraged to pledge to donate proceeds to "good causes".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://carrierbagchargescotland.org.uk/|accessdate=2015-10-21|title=Home – Carrier Bag Charge Scotland}}</ref> The charge is not exclusive to plastic bags, and includes [[biodegradable]] bags, such as paper.<ref name=independent-scot /> Bags for unpackaged food, loose seeds, soil-contaminated goods, axes, knives or blades; drugs or medical appliances; small packaged uncooked fish, meat or poultry; aquatic animals; purchases made in [[Airport security|aerodrome security restricted areas]]; or goods bought on board a ship, train, aircraft, coach or bus are exempt from the charge.<ref>{{cite law|url=http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ssi/2014/161/schedule/paragraph/1/made|title=The Single Use Carrier Bags Charge (Scotland) Regulations 2014|article=1|articletype=Schedule|accessdate=2015-10-21|year=2014|number=161}}</ref>
=====England===== [[England]] was the last country in the United Kingdom to adopt the 5 pence charge,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-34346309|title=The 5p plastic bag charge: All you need to know|last=Howell|first=Dominic|date=2016-07-30|newspaper=BBC News|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-11-15}}</ref> with the levy taking effect on 5 October 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.itv.com/news/2015-09-16/5p-carrier-bag-fee-will-cost-families-1-5-billion-over-next-10-years/|title=5p carrier bag fee 'will cost families £1.5 billion' over next 10 years|work=ITV News|accessdate=6 October 2015}}</ref> Prior to the introduction of plastic bag regulations, various retailers participated in voluntary actions to reduce plastic bag consumption.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1111/j.1470-6431.2009.00749.x |title=Plastic bag politics: Modifying consumer behaviour for sustainable development |journal=International Journal of Consumer Studies |volume=33 |issue=2 |pages=168–174 |year=2009 |last1=Ritch |first1=Elaine |last2=Brennan |first2=Carol |last3=MacLeod |first3=Calum }}</ref>
Unlike the rest of the UK, the English charge does not apply to paper bags or bags made from other natural materials. As with the other nations, [[Value added tax|VAT]] raised on sales will be collected by the Government. Retailers can choose how the money raised from bag sales is used. The Government publishes information yearly on the scheme, encouraging retailers to donate the proceeds to charities.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-34346309|title=The 5p plastic bag charge: All you need to know|newspaper=BBC News|accessdate=6 October 2015|date=2016-07-30|last1=Howell|first1=Dominic}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Carrier bags: why there's a charge |url=https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/single-use-plastic-carrier-bags-why-were-introducing-the-charge/carrier-bags-why-theres-a-5p-charge |publisher=[[Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs]] |date=3 November 2015 |accessdate=24 November 2015}}</ref>
In the first 6 months, 640 million plastic bags were used in seven major supermarkets in England, raising £29.2 million for good causes.<ref>{{Cite news |title=BBC News:Plastic bag use plummets in England |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-36917174 |publisher=[[Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs]] |date=30 July 2016 |accessdate=30 July 2016|newspaper=BBC News |last1=Morelle |first1=Rebecca }}</ref> England reported to have distributed 0.6 billion single-use bags during the first half year of the charge,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/carrier-bag-charge-summary-of-data-in-england-for-2015-to-2016/single-use-plastic-carrier-bags-charge-data-in-england-for-2015-to-2016|title=Single-use plastic carrier bags charge: data in England for 2015 to 2016 – GOV.UK|website=www.gov.uk|access-date=2016-11-15}}</ref> 7 billion fewer than were distributed in 2014.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.wrap.org.uk/2015_carrier_bag_figures|title=WRAP announces new carrier bag figures {{!}} WRAP UK|date=2015-07-22|website=www.wrap.org.uk|access-date=2016-11-15}}</ref>
To promote the growth of new businesses in England, retailers with fewer than 250 employees are exempt from the charge.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Everett|first=Michael|last2=Priestley|first2=Sara|title=The 5p Plastic Bag Charge|url=http://researchbriefings.parliament.uk/ResearchBriefing/Summary/CBP-7241|date=2017-06-22}}</ref> Opponents to the exemption of small retailers argued that this exemption would diminish the environmental impact of the charge.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.parliament.uk/business/committees/committees-a-z/commons-select/environmental-audit-committee/news/plasticbagsgvtresponse/|title=Plastic bags: Government response – News from Parliament|website=UK Parliament|access-date=2016-11-16}}</ref> In response to this criticism, in the UK government has announced plans to extend the charge to all retailers and double the charge to 10p.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-42630898|title=5p plastic bag charge set to be extended|date=11 January 2018|publisher=|via=www.bbc.co.uk|newspaper=BBC News}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.sky.com/story/plastic-bag-charge-to-double-to-10p-and-will-also-affect-smaller-retailers-11481388|title=Plastic bag charge to 'double to 10p and will also affect smaller retailers'|publisher=|accessdate=27 August 2018}}</ref>
====Falkland Islands==== The [[Falkland Islands]] has a voluntary agreement in place where retailers charge for bags and donate the proceeds to charity.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chandlery.co.fk/fig-press-statement.html|title=FIG Press Statement|website=www.chandlery.co.fk|accessdate=9 August 2018}}</ref>

==== Antigua and Barbuda ==== There is a plastic bag ban in place in [[Antigua and Barbuda]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://appliedecology.cals.ncsu.edu/absci/2016/07/antigua-and-barbuda-bans-plastic-bags/|title=Antigua and Barbuda bans plastic bags|publisher=|accessdate=27 November 2017}}</ref>
==== Bahamas ==== The Bahamas government has announced a plan to ban plastic bags by 2020.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.plasticpollutioncoalition.org/pft/2018/1/22/the-bahamas-to-ban-plastic-bags|title=The Bahamas To Ban Plastic Bags|publisher=|accessdate=22 January 2018}}</ref>
==== Belize ==== Belize has pledged to ban plastic bags by 22 April 2019 ([[Earth Day]]).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://mic.com/articles/188565/belize-pledges-to-ban-plastic-forks-bags-and-other-single-use-items-by-2019#.dilSphOr1|title=Belize pledges to ban plastic forks, bags and other single-use items by 2019|publisher=|accessdate=22 March 2018}}</ref>
==== Canada ==== In March 2007, the small town of [[Leaf Rapids]], Manitoba, became the first community in North America to ban bags.<ref name="LeafRapids">{{cite news|title=Plastic bags officially banned in Manitoba town|url=http://www.ctvnews.ca/plastic-bags-officially-banned-in-manitoba-town-1.235770|accessdate=25 February 2016|publisher=Bell Media|date=2 April 2007}}</ref>
The [[Toronto]] City Council voted on 6 June 2012, to ban plastic bags effective 1 January 2013, and to scrap the city's five-cent bag fee starting 1 July 2012.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.torontosun.com/2012/06/06/toronto-bans-plastic-bags-by-the-start-of-2013| title=Toronto bans plastic bags by the start of 2013| date=6 June 2012| publisher=The Toronto Sun| accessdate=8 November 2012}}</ref> Industry groups have convinced city officials to include a grace period between 1 January 2013, and 30 June 2013, when no fines, only warnings, can be issued.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.thestar.com/news/gta/cityhallpolitics/article/1284505| title=Toronto plastic bag ban: Bylaw ready to go for a Jan. 1 soft launch| date=7 November 2012| publisher=The Toronto Star| accessdate=8 November 2012}}</ref> The bag ban and five cent fee (six cents with [[Harmonized Sales Tax|HST]]) have both been overturned as of 28 November 2012 and it's up to individual retailers if they want to charge for plastic bags.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cp24.com/news/bag-ban-overturned-shopping-bylaw-unchanged-1.1057255|title=Bag ban overturned, shopping bylaw unchanged|work=CP24|accessdate=6 October 2015|date=2012-11-28}}</ref> Most stores, with the exception of a few national retailers do not charge.

==== Guatemala ==== A few municipalities in Guatemala have banned plastic bags, including [[San Pedro La Laguna]], [[Acatenango, Chimaltenango|Acatenango]], [[Villa Canales]], [[San Miguel Petapa]] and [[Totonicapán]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://globalpressjournal.com/americas/guatemala/to-help-conserve-lake-atitlan-town-bans-plastic-bags/|title=To Help Conserve Lake Atitlán, Town Bans Plastic Bags|date=4 May 2017|publisher=|accessdate=22 March 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.soy502.com/articulo/acatenango-prohibe-uso-venta-distribucion-bolsas-plasticas-50172|title=Acatenango prohíbe el uso de bolsas plásticas, pajillas y duroport|access-date=2018-06-30|language=es}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://elperiodico.com.gt/nacion/2018/06/14/municipalidad-de-villa-canales-prohibe-el-uso-de-bolsas-plasticas-y-otros-articulos-no-reusables/|title=Municipalidad de Villa Canales prohíbe el uso de bolsas plásticas y otros artículos no reusables|work=elPeriodico|access-date=2018-06-30}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.prensalibre.com/ciudades/guatemala/san-miguel-petapa-se-une-a-la-prohibicion-de-bolsas-plasticas|title=San Miguel Petapa se une a la prohibición de bolsas plásticas|work=Prensa Libre|access-date=2018-06-30}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://medium.com/@PrensaComunitar/totonicap%C3%A1n-dice-no-al-uso-del-pl%C3%A1stico-75b1ca5654f1|title=Totonicapán dice NO al uso del plástico|last=KM169|first=Prensa Comunitaria|date=2018-06-05|website=Prensa Comunitaria KM169|access-date=2018-06-30}}</ref>
==== Haiti ==== Haiti has banned plastic bags.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/aug/15/haiti-police-raid-plastics-ban-crackdown|title=Haiti police raid warehouses in plastics ban crackdown|first=Rashmee Roshan|last=Lall|date=15 August 2013|publisher=|accessdate=27 November 2017|via=www.theguardian.com|newspaper=The Guardian}}</ref>
==== Jamaica ==== There is a working group examining a state motion to ban plastic bags in Jamaica.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://jamaica-gleaner.com/article/news/20170825/last-day-feedback-proposal-ban-plastic-bags|title=Last day for feedback on proposal to ban plastic bags|website=jamaica-gleaner.com|accessdate=27 November 2017|date=2017-08-25}}</ref>
On 17 September 2018, the [[Cabinet of Jamaica|Jamaican Cabinet]] announced a total ban on the importation, manufacture, distribution and use of single-use plastic bags, effective 1 January 2019.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jamaicaobserver.com/latestnews/Gov%26%238217;t_ban_on_single_use_plastic_bags,_straws,_Styrofoam_starts_January|work=Jamaica Observer|date=17 September 2018|accessdate=18 September 2018|title=Gov't ban on single use plastic bags, straws, Styrofoam starts January}}</ref>
==== Mexico ==== [[Mexico]] approved legislation to ban and fine plastic bags in August 2010. However, the legislation is not observed.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.plasticsnews.com/article/20110804/NEWS/308049978| title=Mexico rejects plastic bag bans, embraces industry plan to boost recycling| date=4 August 2011| publisher= Plastic News| accessdate=2 November 2013}}</ref> Mexico City banned plastic bags in 2010, but plastic bags remain one of Mexico's biggest pollution problems.<ref>{{Cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-11032252| title=Mexico City bans free plastic bags| date=19 August 2010| publisher= British Broadcasting Corporation| accessdate=3 July 2012| newspaper=BBC News}}</ref> The [[Querétaro City|city of Querétaro]] banned plastic bags in 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://mexiconewsdaily.com/news/municipality-is-first-to-outlaw-plastic-bags/|title=Querétaro is first municipality in Mexico to outlaw plastic bags|date=15 December 2017|publisher=|accessdate=22 March 2018}}</ref>
==== Panama ==== Panama's Assembly has passed legislation banning plastic bags.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://panamaadvisoryinternationalgroup.com/blog/news-from-panama/plastic-bags-banned-panama/|title=Plastic Bags Banned in Panama – THE PANAMA PERSPECTIVE|date=16 August 2017|publisher=|accessdate=27 November 2017}}</ref> The law was sanctioned by the president in January 2017 and retailers have until January 2020 to phase out their existing stock.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.audubon.org/news/panama-bans-use-plastic-bags|work=Audubon|date=7 February 2018|title=Panama Bans the Use of Plastic Bags}}</ref>
==== United States ==== There is no national plastic bag fee or ban currently in effect in the [[United States]]. However, the state of California,<ref name="cal-16">{{cite news|last1=Luna|first1=Taryn|title=Californians say farewell to the plastic bag|url=http://www.sacbee.com/news/politics-government/capitol-alert/article113898813.html|accessdate=14 November 2016|work=The Sacramento Bee|date=10 November 2016}}</ref> and the territories of American Samoa and Puerto Rico<ref name="puertorico">{{cite web|last1=Coto|first1=Danica|title=Puerto Rico to ban use of plastic bags through executive order after legislators opposed bill|url=https://www.usnews.com/news/business/articles/2015/10/30/puerto-rico-to-ban-plastic-bags-through-executive-order|publisher=U.S. News & World Report|accessdate=7 January 2016|date=30 October 2015}}</ref> have banned [[disposable]] bags. Over 200 [[County (United States)|counties]] and municipalities have enacted ordinances either imposing a fee on plastic bags or banning them outright, including all counties in Hawaii.<ref>{{cite web|last=Llanos|first=Miguel|title=Hawaii first state to ban plastic bags at checkout |url=http://usnews.nbcnews.com/_news/2012/05/16/11720480-hawaii-first-state-to-ban-plastic-bags-at-checkout?lite |publisher=NBC News |accessdate=23 April 2013 |date=16 May 2012}}</ref> Other attempts at banning plastic shopping bags statewide (for example in [[Massachusetts]]) have not succeeded mainly due to [[Progressive Bag Alliance|plastic industry lobbying]].<ref>{{cite news|title=This time, pass California ban on plastic bags: Editorial|url=http://www.dailynews.com/news/ci_23056218/this-time-pass-california-ban-plastic-bags-editorial?source=rss|newspaper=Los Angeles Daily News|accessdate=23 April 2013|date=18 April 2013}}</ref> A few jurisdictions have chosen to implement a fee-only approach to bag reduction such as [[Washington, D.C.]] and adjacent [[Montgomery County, Maryland]].<ref name=WRN>{{cite news|last=Verespej|first=Nike|title=Massachusetts town bans plastic bags|url=http://www.wasterecyclingnews.com/article/20121116/NEWS03/121119931/massachusetts-town-bans-plastic-bags|accessdate=29 November 2012|newspaper=Waste & Recycling News|date=16 November 2012}}</ref> Some US states, such as [[Florida]] and [[Arizona]], have passed laws preventing local municipalities from passing their own bans.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Frazier|first1=Ian|title=The Bag Bill|url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2016/05/02/saving-america-from-plastic-bags|accessdate=29 April 2016|publisher=The New Yorker}}</ref>

===== California ===== Californians voted in November 2016 to approve state legislation banning plastic bags statewide in Propositions [[California Proposition 67 (2016)|67]] and [[California Proposition 65 (2016)|65]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2016/11/7/13551320/science-issues-election-2016-measures-climate-energy-health-marijuana|title=10 science issues at stake in the 2016 election|first=Alessandra|last=Potenza|date=7 November 2016|publisher=The Verge}}</ref> Over 100 local laws with similar or tougher regulations will remain and supersede the statewide legislation.
